creator: donnie-armstrong@mn.rr.com
text:
If the <filtersfile file="" /> is changed, ant should regenerate new copies.

My copy filter target below:

<!-- Copy config files to the temp directory, replacing tokens as required -->
<copy todir="${pkg.config.dir}">
  <fileset dir="${pkg.source.dir}" />
  <filterset>
    <filtersfile file="${env.props.dir}/${target.env}.properties"/>
  </filterset>
</copy>

Only with the overwrite="true" on the <copy /> task will force a regeneration of
the files.  I am not sure this is the intention of the overwrite attribute.

creator: mbenson@apache.org
text:
How is Ant supposed to keep track of the filtersfile from one build to the next?
 If you want this you will have to implement it yourself externally to <copy>. 
If you need this, you might find the <modified> file selector useful.

creator: ville@oikarinen.org
text:
The same way it "keeps track" of the source files: by comparing their timestamp 
to the timestamp of the target files.

Of course, if the design of the filter implementations makes it _difficult_ 
(not all filter types are file-based) it's understandable that this bug won't 
be fixed.

But it would be _possible_, though.

Kind regards,
Ville Oikarinen

creator: peterreilly@apache.org
text: You can use uptodate or antlib:net.sf.contrib:outofdate to do the comparision.
